turns.speaker: RANGER
turns.text: Number three to. D.O....Number three to D.O.

turns.speaker: RADIO VOICE
turns.text: D.O. to number three..come in.

turns.speaker: RANGER
turns.text: We're getting this under control. Won't need any more help.  Over.

turns.speaker: RADIO VOICE
turns.text: Okay.  Send the tanker in, but you stand by until that thing cools off. Over.

turns.speaker: RANGER
turns.text: I think somebody ought to check on it. Over.

turns.speaker: RADIO VOICE
turns.text: Well, there's some fellows fishing at Pine Summit might be interested.  They probably saw it come down.  I'll let 'em know...What's it look like?

turns.speaker: WASH PERRY
turns.text: Better'n a lion farm or a snake pit. We won't have to feed it!

turns.speaker: SALVADOR
turns.text: We sell the tamales, enchiladas - hot dogs!

turns.speaker: WASH PERRY
turns.text: Must be somebody in there.

turns.speaker: SALVADOR
turns.text: Who?  Where d'you think they come from!

turns.speaker: WASH PERRY
turns.text: How would I know...!

turns.speaker: SALVADOR
turns.text: Maybe these are not men - not like us.

turns.speaker: WASH PERRY
turns.text: Everything human don't have to look like you and me....

turns.speaker: SALVADOR
turns.text: What'll we say to 'em?

turns.speaker: WASH PERRY
turns.text: Welcome to California!

turns.speaker: WASH PERRY
turns.text: They'll understand us, all right!

turns.speaker: SALVADOR
turns.text: Sure, sure!  Everybody understands you wave the white flag, you wanna be friends.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: I thought you'd killed Freddy off.

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: We did.  Bad mistake.  The fans are clamoring for more. So, Evil never dies, right?  Anyway, a while back we got a call from Wes.  He's got this idea.  And who better to resurrect Freddy than his creator?

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: I thought he'd stopped doing horror.

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: Believe it or not, he told me I hadn't heard from him in ten years because he hasn't had any good nightmare.  They're his inspiration.  But now he's got a new script in the works.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Which means he's having nightmares again?

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: He's very excited about it.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: The nightmares.

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: He's excited about the script.  You should be too.  It stars you.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Can I read it?

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: He's not showing it until it's down.  But it sounds hot, and we wanted to get all our stars lined up in case it is.  You and Robert got great ratings today. Which is the first thing we needed to know.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: You mean that was a...

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: Sort of a trial balloon.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: I don't know, Bob.  I'm flattered and all, but I've got a kid, now.

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: So?

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: So I don't know about horror.

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: Come on.  Kids love horror.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: And I...I've got other things happening.

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: I'm sure we can match any offer.

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: Sweetie, you've got lots of fans, we've done market studies.  You rate right up there.  We've already got Chase working on a prototype for the glove.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: I know.  We asked him to keep it kind of surprise until we talked.  Look, how about we get in touch your agent.  You still with Jerry?

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Yes, but...

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: We'll work something out.  I'm sure you'll be happy with it.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Bob, how long has Wes been working on this script?

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: I don't know.  A couple months.  Why?

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: And since you've been thinking of making it.  Has anything funny happened?

turns.speaker: BOB
turns.text: I don't follow.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Like weird calls, by any chance?

turns.speaker: CHASE
turns.text: Might as well be, Dylan.  State of the art animatronics enhanced with bio- organic grafting.  Bull tendons, nerve bundles from a Doberman, even half the brain of a homicidal primate was...

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Chase...

turns.speaker: CHASE
turns.text: Just an earthquake, Dylan.  Every once in a while we get a few.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: No biggie, really.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: One of mom's cups got broken.

turns.speaker: CHASE
turns.text: I'm sorry.  At least we're in on piece.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Dylan, it's breakfast.  Not arts and crafts  What?

turns.speaker: CHASE
turns.text: You get any sleep last night?

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: More or less.  Dylan, time to get dressed.  I'm late.

turns.speaker: CHASE
turns.text: Anything other than the obvious bothering you?

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Five earthquakes in three weeks is enough.

turns.speaker: CHASE
turns.text: Hasn't been another call, has there?

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Maybe.  Or maybe I shouldn't do this interview today.

turns.speaker: CHASE
turns.text: You've got to get back on the horse some time.  Look, you've had a nutcase making harassing phone calls.  I know how scary that feels.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: No, you don't.

turns.speaker: CHASE
turns.text: Okay, but it still doesn't mean it can't be over with.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: What if it isn't over?

turns.speaker: CHASE
turns.text: Maybe you should tell me your dream.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: It was nothing.  We were both working on some movie, and a special effects thing went horribly wrong.  Terry and Chuck were...hurt.  You were almost...  You were even cut.

turns.speaker: CHASE
turns.text: You probably were half awake and saw me get nicked by that picture glass.  Dreams work like that.  You want me not to go on this job?

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Just be careful, okay?

turns.speaker: CHASE
turns.text: I should survive two days in Palmdale supplying soap bubbles for a detergent commercial, don't you think?

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Guess so.

turns.speaker: CHASE
turns.text: 48 hours.  Back before you know it.

turns.speaker: CHASE
turns.text: Heather?

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Chase. Hi...

turns.speaker: CHASE
turns.text: What's up?

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Chase, you'd better come home.

turns.speaker: CHASE
turns.text: Heather, I'm stuck here.  Neither Chuck or Terry came in today.  I can't get away!

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Chase, it's Dylan!

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: He's had some sort of...episode.

turns.speaker: CHASE
turns.text: What?  What kind of episode?

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: He was just acting very strange.  He thinks somebody's after him, Chase. It's scary, it scared me.  He was acting like...

turns.speaker: CHASE
turns.text: Like what?

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Like Freddy.

turns.speaker: CHASE
turns.text: Heather, has there been another call?

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Chase.  Why didn't Chuck or Terry show up?

turns.speaker: CHASE
turns.text: Forget those two clowns, Heather.  Answer me, did you get another call from that guy or not?

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: CHASE
turns.text: I'll be there in three hours.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Don't speed, Chase.  It's not...

turns.speaker: DR. HEFNER
turns.text: Any history of epilepsy in your family?

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: DR. HEFNER
turns.text: Diabetes?

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: DR. HEFNER
turns.text: Was there any trigger event?  A trauma, shock or...  You haven't shown him any of the films you make, have you?  The horror stuff?

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: No...

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Does he have to stay here over night?

turns.speaker: DR. HEFNER
turns.text: Absolutely.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Like what?

turns.speaker: DR. HEFNER
turns.text: Sometimes what a child says or fantasizes will give a clue to what ails him.  Did he say anything while he was still lucid?

turns.speaker: DR. HEFNER
turns.text: Ms. Langenkamp.  I'm afraid there are no evening visiting hours in Intensive Care.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Is he all right?

turns.speaker: DR. HEFNER
turns.text: Dylan?  He's holding well.  Earlier he had some problems, he's in an oxygen tent just now...

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Oh my God...

turns.speaker: DR. HEFNER
turns.text: If these had been a few inches nearer to the wrist... What did you say you cut yourself on?

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: It was an earthquake and it was dark.  I have no idea.

turns.speaker: DR. HEFNER
turns.text: These look quite fresh.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: They are...it happened in tonight's quake.  It happened just fifteen minutes ago. You must've felt it.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Doctor...

turns.speaker: DR. HEFNER
turns.text: Get her back!  I've got to go in!  Get me a full anesthetic, STAT!

turns.speaker: DR. HEFNER
turns.text: Ms. Langenkamp.  I suggest you go home and get some rest.  Your son is fine. He's been taken downstairs for further testing.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: He was just here!

turns.speaker: DR. HEFNER
turns.text: He was here.  You fell asleep.  We took him.  You looked so exhausted, frankly, we didn't wake you.  Besides, the young woman, Julie, is with him.  Believe me, everything is fine.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Everything is not fine!

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: DO you mind...

turns.speaker: DR. HEFNER
turns.text: Just a quick word, Ms. Langenkamp.  For Dylan's sake.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: I want my kid out of here now!

turns.speaker: DR. HEFNER
turns.text: Very well. As soon as we gather the appropriate papers...

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: You don't understand.  If Dylan falls asleep,then...

turns.speaker: DR. HEFNER
turns.text: No way he's going anywhere.  He's been well sedated.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: He doesn't have to be awake to be on his feet.

turns.speaker: DR. HEFNER
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: He sleepwalks, you idiot!  He's fully capable of walking out of this hospital.  Oh my God...He thinks I've gone home...

turns.speaker: DYLAN
turns.text: no.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: You have a fever, sweetie?

turns.speaker: DYLAN
turns.text: You going away?

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Just for a few hours.  Julie'll be with you.

turns.speaker: DYLAN
turns.text: Someone's coming.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Dylan, I gotta go.  Forgive me?

turns.speaker: DYLAN
turns.text: Bye.

turns.speaker: DYLAN
turns.text: Rex saved me.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Rex?  Who's Rex?

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: "...as soon as the sun was up the witch made Gretel fetch the wood and kindle a fire.  'We will bake cookies first,' she said.  'I have heated the oven and kneaded the dough.  Crawl in and see if the fire is blazing high enough now.' And she pushed Gretel toward the oven. The witch meant to shut the door and bake her once she was inside."  Dylan, this is too violent.  I don't know why you like these stupid old tales.

turns.speaker: DYLAN
turns.text: Finish, please!

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: This is going to give you nightmares.

turns.speaker: DYLAN
turns.text: I like this story.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Time for sleep.

turns.speaker: DYLAN
turns.text: Say how they find their way back home.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Tomorrow night.

turns.speaker: DYLAN
turns.text: No.  Tonight.  It's important!

turns.speaker: DYLAN
turns.text: "Then their father covered them with kisses and they were safe."

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: They were safe and could sleep.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: DYLAN
turns.text: The mean old man with the claws.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Okay, sweetie, night, night, sleep tight.

turns.speaker: DYLAN
turns.text: Don't let the bedbugs bite.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: He's on his way.

turns.speaker: DYLAN
turns.text: He can follow the breadcrumbs, right?

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Right.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Mommy's fine, Dylan.  Just had a bad dream.  What're you doing out of bed?

turns.speaker: DYLAN
turns.text: Rex woke me up. He was fighting.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Dylan, you go back to sleep now.

turns.speaker: DYLAN
turns.text: Not sleepy.

turns.speaker: DYLAN
turns.text: I can't sleep there, Mommy.  Please!

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: You've got to sleep, Dylan, you...

turns.speaker: DYLAN
turns.text: In my bed.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Your bed?

turns.speaker: DYLAN
turns.text: Under my covers.  Kids singing, and way down there, the man...the mean man...

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: And...what's the man doing?

turns.speaker: DYLAN
turns.text: Trying to get up...trying to get into our world.

turns.speaker: DYLAN
turns.text: Do you have to die to see God?

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: No, I don't think so.  You just have to...pray, or reach...

turns.speaker: DYLAN
turns.text: Why does God let there be bad things?

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: I honestly don't know. Try to sleep, baby.

turns.speaker: DYLAN
turns.text: Can you come with me in my dreams?

turns.speaker: DYLAN
turns.text: Home.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Home, that's right.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: You okay, champ?

turns.speaker: DYLAN
turns.text: Can we go get Rex, now?  The bad man's getting awful close.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: I know he is, sweetie.  We'll both go get Rex right now.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Tell you what.  I'm gonna go get Rex for you right now.  You know home isn't far from here, right?

turns.speaker: DYLAN
turns.text: Right 'cross the freeway.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: That's right.  So I won't be long. Meanwhile Julie's gonna be right here with you.

turns.speaker: DYLAN
turns.text: Hurry back, please.  I'm sleepy.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Promise.  Cross my heart.  But until Mommy gets back, Dylan, whatever you do, don't fall asleep.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: You saw him, didn't you, Dylan!?

turns.speaker: DYLAN
turns.text: Coming for you...

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Dylan, where's the man?

turns.speaker: DYLAN
turns.text: Here.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: What...what is that?

turns.speaker: DYLAN
turns.text: A story?

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Yes.  It's a story.  A story for a movie.

turns.speaker: DYLAN
turns.text: Read me some?

turns.speaker: ROBERT ENGLUND
turns.text: You okay?

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: I'm fine.

turns.speaker: ROBERT ENGLUND
turns.text: Everything went great, I thought.  We really got you, didn't we?

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: I don't know why you didn't tell me, that's all.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: In what, a romantic comedy?

turns.speaker: ROBERT ENGLUND
turns.text: Just because it's a love story doesn't mean it can't have a decapitation or two.

turns.speaker: ROBERT ENGLUND
turns.text: Heather?  You doing okay?

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Holding my own.  You know that guy who was calling me all the time?  He's started again.  He's been putting stuff in my mail.

turns.speaker: ROBERT ENGLUND
turns.text: Must've read about the funeral.  Sick mother.  That's the last thing you need right now, I'm sure.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: It's actually been giving me Freddy nightmares.

turns.speaker: ROBERT ENGLUND
turns.text: Darker.  More...evil?

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Yeah...how'd you know?

turns.speaker: ROBERT ENGLUND
turns.text: Call it a guess...

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Anyway, what I was calling about was...have you seen any of the script, by any chance?

turns.speaker: ROBERT ENGLUND
turns.text: Wes won't show it until it's finished. That's what he told me, at least.  I asked him at the funeral.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: When do you think it'll be done?

turns.speaker: ROBERT ENGLUND
turns.text: The way he's writing is so weird, who knows?  I asked him how far he'd gotten at the funeral, and what was it he said...?  Oh yeah, as far as Dylan trying to reach God.  Weird, huh, that he'd have your kid in it?

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: What...happened?

turns.speaker: JOHN SAXON
turns.text: Quake knocked you off your feet.  You got bumped pretty good, actually.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: I know what he's doing is bizarre, but most of the time he seems so normal, so well adjusted.  I just can't believe it's him.  I mean, and not something outside, influencing him.  Or is that how denial works?

turns.speaker: JOHN SAXON
turns.text: When it is denial.  I don't think that's the case here, but if you're really worried, have a doctor check him out. You'll see, everything's fine.

turns.speaker: JOHN SAXON
turns.text: You're not crazy, by the way.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Thinking I saw Freddy in the grave feels pretty crazy.  And jumping in...

turns.speaker: JOHN SAXON
turns.text: You didn't jump in.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: That's my memory.  And it seemed absolutely real.

turns.speaker: JOHN SAXON
turns.text: Seemed, not was.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: It's in my family, you know.  My grandmother died in an institution...

turns.speaker: JOHN SAXON
turns.text: Really?  Hell, if having a screwy family made you crazy, the world'd be one colossal nuthouse.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: I've never mentioned it to him.

turns.speaker: JOHN SAXON
turns.text: Kids know when something's bugging a parent.  You've got no idea who this is calling?

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Freddy, for all I know.

turns.speaker: JOHN SAXON
turns.text: Steady...

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: A man, or a boy with a deep, y'know, Freddy voice.

turns.speaker: JOHN SAXON
turns.text: Six weeks of this, and you're surprised you've got Freddy in your dreams?  Hell, Sonny Bono says after a while he was seeing his stalker everywhere.  Even at Mass.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Really?

turns.speaker: JOHN SAXON
turns.text: Absolutely.  And how many times has Letterman called the cops thinking that woman was down in his kitchen again?  It gets under your skin if you let it.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: You really think Dylan's okay?

turns.speaker: JOHN SAXON
turns.text: John Saxon.  Do you have any idea what time it is?

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: John.  It's Heather.  I need help!

turns.speaker: JOHN SAXON
turns.text: You got it.  What's happening?

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Dylan's run away from the hospital.  I don't know whether he's wandering around or heading for the house.  But I think Freddy's after him.  I know it sounds crazy!

turns.speaker: JOHN SAXON
turns.text: You're right.  That sounds crazy!

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: John.  Will you please just look for him around the hospital?  I'm gonna go right to the house.  Will you help me, John?  Please!

turns.speaker: JOHN SAXON
turns.text: Holy...

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Where's Dylan?!  Have you seen him?

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: I know how Chase really died.

turns.speaker: JOHN SAXON
turns.text: What are you talking about?

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Fred Krueger did it.

turns.speaker: JOHN SAXON
turns.text: Yeah, sure.

turns.speaker: HIGHWAY PATROLMAN #1
turns.text: Heather Langenkamp?

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: HIGHWAY PATROLMAN #1
turns.text: Is Chase Porter your husband?

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: HIGHWAY PATROLMAN #1
turns.text: I'm afraid there was an accident.  It appears he fell asleep while driving, ma'am.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: I want to see the body.

turns.speaker: HIGHWAY PATROLMAN #1
turns.text: No, you don't, ma'am, it's not necessary.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: I want to see for myself.

turns.speaker: MAN'S VOICE
turns.text: Studio B.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Hi.  This is Heather Langenkamp.

turns.speaker: MAN'S VOICE
turns.text: The car's no there yet?

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: No.  I...listen, I can't make it in today.

turns.speaker: MAN'S VOICE
turns.text: You're kidding, right?

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: I'm sorry, I can't.

turns.speaker: MAN'S VOICE
turns.text: Listen, dammit.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: I just can't.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Yeah, Julie, I'm sorry.  I just thought...there was an earthquake, I think.  Little one, but...

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Big truck went right by before you opened the door.  Life on the Fault Line.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Heather, what is it?

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Dunno.  Just have this feeling today...

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: I'll call the cops for you.  You've got the number on the fridge, right?

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Thanks.  Just give them the time he called.  They're keeping a list, supposedly.  Sorry.  My nerves are so raw these days.

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: 'S okay.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: No, Rex is not going to die.  Julie, you know where the sewing stuff is, don't you?

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: Sure.  We'll do an operation, Doctor Dylan and Doctor Julie. We'll fix him good as new.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: No, I don't think that at all.  How is he?

turns.speaker: JULIE
turns.text: They wouldn't let me...

turns.speaker: WES
turns.text: I can tell you what the nightmares are about.  They're about this...entity. Whatever you want to call it.  It's old, very old, and it's taken different forms in different times.  The only thing that stays the same about it is what it lives for.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: WES
turns.text: Killing innocence, one way or the other.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: This is still a script we're talking about, right?

turns.speaker: WES
turns.text: I think of it as sort of a nightmare in progress.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Then, in this nightmare in progress, does this thing have any weaknesses?

turns.speaker: WES
turns.text: It can be captured, sometimes.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Captured?  How?

turns.speaker: WES
turns.text: By storytellers, of all things.  Every so often, they imagine a story good enough to catch its essence.  Then it's held prisoner for a while.  In the story.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Like the Genie in the bottle.

turns.speaker: WES
turns.text: Exactly.  The problem comes when the story dies. It happens a lot of different ways, the story gets too familiar, or too watered down by people trying to make it easier to sell, or ti's labeled a threat to society and just plain banned.  However it happens, when the story dies, the evil is set free.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: You saying Freddy's this ancient thing?

turns.speaker: WES
turns.text: Current version.  For ten years he's been imprisoned as Freddy by the story of Nightmare on Elm Street.  But now that the films have stopped-  The genie's out of the bottle, Heather, that's what the nightmares are about. That's what I'm writing.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: If Freddy's loose, I mean, in your script, where's he going to go?  Another age?  Another form?

turns.speaker: WES
turns.text: That's not what the dreams say he's doing.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Then what is he doing?

turns.speaker: WES
turns.text: Well, see, he's gotten used to being Freddy now.  And kinda likes it here in our time and space, too.  So...he's trying to cross over, from film into our reality.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Isn't there anyone that can stop him?

turns.speaker: WES
turns.text: Interestingly enough, in the dreams there is one person.  A gatekeeper, so to speak.  Someone Freddy's got to get by before he can enter our world.  It's you, Heather.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Me?  Why me?

turns.speaker: WES
turns.text: Dramatically speaking it makes perfect sense.  You played Nancy, after all, the first to humiliate and defeat him.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: That was Nancy, not me!

turns.speaker: WES
turns.text: But it was you that gave Nancy her strength.  So to get out he has to come through you.  And it's inevitable that he'll hit you at your most vulnerable points...

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Dylan.  And...  Chase.  My God, Wes, did you know?

turns.speaker: WES
turns.text: Heather, it's just a movie, a dream, really...

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: You know damn well it's more than that now!  How can we stop him?

turns.speaker: WES
turns.text: The way to stop him is to make another movie.  And I swear to you I'll stay at my computer and keep writing until I finish the script.  But when that time comes...  You're gonna have to make a choice.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Choice?  What kind of choice?

turns.speaker: WES
turns.text: Whether or not you're willing to play Nancy one last time.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: I don't know if it has, really.  With the exception of One and Three, I've pretty much kept out of it.  I'm working in television now.  The hours let me spend more time with my husband and little boy.

turns.speaker: HOST
turns.text: Now that you have a child, is it possible you've decided horror is bad for children?

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: No, not really.  I...

turns.speaker: HOST
turns.text: Do you let your child watch your movies?

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: My child?  No...but...

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Of course he is.  Freddy's dead and gone.

turns.speaker: HOST
turns.text: And how about your co-star in NIGHTMARE I.  Would you trust him alone with your child?

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Robert?  I...

turns.speaker: HOST
turns.text: Maybe we should ask him, hmmm?  We've got a surprised, Heather.  A great big surprise for you and our audience.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: Heather, this is Sara Risher over at New Line.  How are you?

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Oh, hi.  I'm fine, Sara.  My God, a voice from the past!

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: Really!  Listen, Heather, I won't take but a minute of your time.  It's just that we have something to propose to you, and wonder if you'd stop by the offices. Bob'd love to talk to you.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Uh...sure...when?

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: No time like the present.  The car will bring you.

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Now?

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: Just take a minute.  You'll be glad you did, I bet.

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: Can I get you something to drink?

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Coffee'd be nice.

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: Sounds good.  Kim, would you get Heather and me a coffee?  How you like it, Hon?

turns.speaker: HEATHER
turns.text: Black's fine.

turns.speaker: SARA
turns.text: Me too.

turns.speaker: SKIPPER
turns.text: Did we lose anybody?

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: Not yet.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: That low passed through last night. May be a little bumpy out there.

turns.speaker: SKIPPER
turns.text: It's time these boys saw some real blue water.

turns.speaker: ALICE
turns.text: Looks like weather.

turns.speaker: SKIPPER
turns.text: Yep.
